11. (i) If \(a_i \geq 0, b_i \geq 0, i = 1, 2, \ldots, n\) and \(p > 1, 1/p + 1/q = 1\), then

\[\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_i b_i \leq \left( \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_i^p \right)^{1/p} \left( \sum_{i=1}^{n} b_i^q \right)^{1/q}.\]

(ii) If \(p \geq 1, \left( \sum_{i=1}^{n} |a_i + b_i|^p \right)^{1/p} \leq \left( \sum_{i=1}^{n} |a_i|^p \right)^{1/p} + \left( \sum_{i=1}^{n} |b_i|^p \right)^{1/p}.\)

(iii) If \(a_i \geq 0, b_i \geq 0, i =1, \ldots, n, \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_i b_i \leq \left( \sum_{\substack{i=1 \\ i \leq n}} a_i \right) \max_{1 \leq i \leq n} b_i\). The proof of (i), for example, is obtained by taking \(X = [1, \ldots, n], a(i) = a_i, \mu([i]) = 1\) so that \(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_i = f a \, d\mu\), and applying Hölder's inequality.
